collections.title: Soft Holding
collections.description: Poems for rest, presence, and letting go of effort.

poems.title: The Way We Sit With Things
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Sometimes healing is not movement
but learning how to stay.
To sit beside what aches
without turning away,
without asking it to hurry.

You do not have to solve the feeling
to be worthy of rest.
You can let it sit on the floor with you,
quiet as a folded coat,
waiting only to be seen.

This is how gentleness begins—
not with answers,
but with presence that does not leave.

poems.title: When You Are Tired
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
There are days your bones remember
things your mind cannot name.
On those days, effort is too loud,
and even hope asks too much.

Let tiredness be honest.
Let it lean its weight against you.
You are allowed to be carried
by stillness for a while.

Nothing important is lost in rest.
Everything essential
waits patiently for your return.

poems.title: A Place to Lay the Day
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Imagine a wide table made of light.
Each moment you carried today
can be placed there gently—
the sharp ones, the quiet ones,
the things you didn’t say.

You don’t need to organize them.
Just set them down.
The table holds without judgment.

When the day is empty of your hands,
you are free again
to breathe as yourself.

poems.title: Soft Holding
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
You don’t have to be strong here.
This place was made for loosening.
For setting armor aside
and letting your shoulders remember
what gravity feels like.

Nothing will fall apart
if you stop holding everything together.
Something kinder may step in instead.

collections.title: Love, Given and Returned
collections.description: Poems about care, exchange, and learning how to receive.

poems.title: The Quiet Work of Love
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Love is rarely loud.
Most of the time
it looks like listening longer than planned,
or staying when leaving would be easier.

Love is the courage
to offer warmth without guarantee.
To give without asking
what it will become.

And somehow,
even when it seems to vanish,
love always finds a way
to return changed,
but not lost.

poems.title: Learning How to Receive
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
You are good at giving.
This much is clear.
But receiving—
that still feels unfamiliar.

Let the kindness land.
Let the help remain unearned.
You don’t need to repay
what was never a debt.

Being held is not weakness.
It is part of the exchange
that keeps us human.

poems.title: The Shape of Care
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Care does not demand perfection.
It asks only for honesty.
For showing up as you are,
not as you rehearse yourself to be.

Care bends around sharp edges.
It learns the shape of your days
and makes room for them.

This is love’s quiet skill—
to fit without force.

poems.title: Munchkin Boo’s Love of You
poems.author: James Ritchie
poems.body:
To you, all of you, our children of this Earth,
From the the farthest fields, in holy matrimony,
In words I find my way.

collections.title: Gentle Becoming
collections.description: Poems about growth that happens quietly and without force.

poems.title: What Grows Slowly
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Nothing meaningful rushes.
Roots take their time
learning the dark.

If you feel behind,
consider the trees.
Consider how long
they stood as nothing visible
at all.

Growth does not announce itself.
It happens quietly,
until one day you realize
you are standing differently.

poems.title: Between Who You Were and Are
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
There is a narrow bridge
between the self you remember
and the one you’re becoming.

You don’t need to name it yet.
Just keep walking.
Each step is enough
even when the view is unclear.

Be patient with the in-between.
It is doing more work
than you can see.

poems.title: A Softer Measure of Progress
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Progress is not always forward.
Sometimes it is downward—
into rest, into truth, into pause.

Sometimes it looks like stopping
before harm repeats itself.

Count these moments, too.
They matter more than you think.

poems.title: Becoming, Gently
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
You are allowed to unfold
without an audience.
To change quietly.
To arrive without announcement.

Gentleness is not delay.
It is precision.

Nothing blooms by force.

collections.title: Kindness as Shelter
collections.description: Poems about warmth, care, and being a place others can rest.

poems.title: What You Offer Others
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Every time you make space
for another person to breathe,
you practice hope.

Kindness is not grand.
It is practical.
It sounds like, “Take your time,”
and means it.

The world survives
on these small mercies.

poems.title: A Place to Be Human
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Let this be a place
where you don’t have to explain yourself.
Where being human
is reason enough to belong.

You are not too much here.
You never were.

poems.title: The Way Kindness Moves
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
Kindness moves like warmth—
it spreads without instruction.
Passed hand to hand,
moment to moment,
until no one remembers
who started it.

This is how healing travels.
Not alone.
Never alone.

poems.title: Shelter
poems.author: Journal Boo
poems.body:
If you do nothing else today,
be shelter.
For yourself, first.

Stand between your heart
and what would harden it.
This, too, is an act of care.

And it matters more
than you know.
